html: This chapter is an abridgment of the foregoing chapter the heads of it are much the same. Here is, I. A woe to those who, when the Assyrian army invaded them, trusted to the Egyptians, and not to God, for succour, . II. Assurance given of the care God would take of Jerusalem in that time of danger and distress, . III. A call to repentance and reformation, . IV. A prediction of the fall of the Assyrian army, and the fright which the Assyrian king should thereby be put into, .
